For those who like to know more about how it came so far: It's a sad story 
about how an idealist politician was suckerpunched by reality.

The whole "school for refugees" was the brainchild of the left-wing 
politician Hans Panhoff, an idealist who was a squatter himself in his 
former years and now part of the city council. His plan to give those 
refugees who had occupied the Oranienplatz some shelter from the winter 
cold resulted in taking the abandoned school for it. It was only meant as 
an interim solution but he had put an immense effort into it, was 
organizing everything and even created special ID cards for everyone in 
that house in order to help everyone. Yet it quickly went out of hand.

There came more and more. At one time over night suddenly 40 roma had 
accomodated into the house. Later there even came up faked ID card. More 
and more quarrels erupted amongst the inhabitants. Panhoff slowly lost 
control despite putting an immense effort into the project and trying to 
help as much as he could.

One day one young man was stabbed to death by another and when a group of 
refugees decided to prohibit Panhoff to enter the yard it was clear that he 
had lost control. When he suggested that the 240 refugees should be 
distributed into other asylums in the city 40 people occupied the roof and 
threatened to jump because they felt it would be an eviction. A lot of them 
strayed for over 2 years now through europe and were already declined in 
other german states or european countries. Some already traumatized by 
civil war. At this time the left-radical scene of berlin started to support 
these people and accused Panhoff of being a racist and fascist who wants to 
put people into camps.

In the end 211 of the 240 inhabitants were willing to leave the house. For 
their sake Panhoff called the police because some of those left-radical 
followers threatened to attack everyone which would want to leave the 
house. What's left were the guys on the roof, a huge amount of protestors 
and 900 policemen guarding the house day and night in shifts. For safety 
reasons the press wasn't allowed to enter the building even though one of 
the biggest german newspapers, the taz filed a lawsuit against it yet the 
court shared the hazard-analysis of the city council.

The situation went on and on until the chief of police said he wouldn't 
give a damn if his man should evacuate the building or retreat from the 
scene but he wouldn't let his police officers be exposed to that situation 
there any longer. Panhoff has lost a lot of backup in his party where a lot 
of the basis already demanded his retirement because in a party with such a 
left-wing history people seem to hold a grudge against him for calling the 
police. His car went up in flames and he now is accompanied by security 
every day as people had threatened his life anonymously. The situation in 
and around the school is still tense yet has become a great party and 
sightseeing attraction for some other. People grill sausages around the 
cordon. Policemen and residents can be seen next to each other, having a 
snack and a little chat while 3000 protesters demand that the illegal 
occupants should be granted a permanent right to stay in the country. The 
situation for the people on the roof is still unsolved.﻿

within 20 years the former European bullies Britain and France were

Not a great report by Vice. No comprehensive back story on the refugees and 
their interaction with the government/legal system, mostly just 
sensationalist bullshit. Of course they can't let you into the grounds or 
building, the situation is clearly escalating and borderline violent, with 
increased physical risk to reporters, police, and government 
workers/civilians if there are media and retarded protesters milling around 
what is essentially a self-imposed hostage situation. I also like how in 
the description they say that the refugees moved into the abandoned school 
after "authorities destroyed their refugee camps." You mean the illegal 
squatter "refugee camps"? That's basically all we know about them. We have 
no context on that demolition--we don't know if they got warnings about it, 
or were told beforehand about alternative places to move (which exist, i.e. 
a real govt. run refugee camp), if they were informed of options they may 
have to gain legal refugee status, etc. etc. This is just a purposely 
inflammatory video of angry, emotional people (we don't know if they're 
justified) yelling at the police and municipal spokesmen. Not enough 
information to make any decent judgement on the situation.﻿

Racism aside, many people don't seem to understand the causes of the 
problem. Refugees come from countries that are torn by civil wars and 
political/racial/religious purges. (Many of these were actually facilitated 
by the Western countries policies, but that's beyond the point.) Almost ALL 
the countries signed the 1951 Convention on refugees because they wanted to 
appear "nice and civilized", but the way each country interprets the 
convention differs WILDLY and is governed by each country's immigration 
policies. So we have members who accept almost everybody and members who 
accept nobody (all signed the same piece of paper!).
Furthermore, many countries have really wishy-washy immigration policies 
that are broken and unclear, so they accept hundreds of thousands of people 
through the border, when they only ready to accommodate maybe a few hundred 
refugees a year. Why? Because politicians don't want to touch the 
immigration laws - it's bad for their image (regardless of what stance you 
take you will be unpopular with half the population - you're either a 
"hippie" or a "nazi" and no in-between). So they just don't deal with it at 
all, cause they want to get re-elected. For decades immigration laws remain 
broken and ineffective, which creates these kind of situations where 
thousands and thousands of people who were let through the border are left 
in limbo and live in the country pretty much illegally. There is a 
civilized way to deal with it - create policies that are working and clear, 
don't let more people in that your country can accommodate, stop trying to 
appear "nice" to everybody. Be frank and blunt, but be real. Unfortunately 
this is NOT how the politics and diplomacy works - it's in fact the 
opposite.
Last but not least, many countries are hostage of their own shit from the 
past. Like colonial Britain and France comes back and bites Brits and 
Frenchmen in the ass to this day. You wanted an empire, so you annexed all 
those 3rd world countries. Then your empire broke apart. But you used those 
people you colonized so much to your benefit, that you had to give them 
preferential treatment as former members of your empire. Things in your 
country and doing better than in your former colonies. Those people have 
the right to come you you (you gave it to them as thank you for all the 
exploitation). Well, guess that they gonna do? Exactly. Wouldn't you have 
done the same if you were one of them? Yes you would.
One thing that people still don't understand is that the world has become 
so interconnected that trouble in one country means trouble for the rest. 
There is no such thing as "that's THEIR problem". Everything is everybody's 
problem now. That's just how it goes. So we can't afford to have wars, 
hunger, poverty anywhere, because you can't build a wall tall enough to 
fence off your little cosy home from the rest of the world. Either help 
them were they live or they will come to where you live - as simple as 
that. It's like you can't be a millionaire living on the same street with 
hungry people, driving your Bentley by them every day and ignore them. 
Hungry people don't stay hungry for long. They will come to your house at 
night.﻿

I try to give some info: after asking for asylum in, let`s say, italy, a

case is decided.
After this, he is a: given asylum; b: not given asylum, but a permission to 
stay or
c: is told to leave on his own till a given date. if he stays onward after 
this date, he might get arrested
and deported by authorities.
Same for the location: after applying for asylum in germany, the people are 
registered and send to a
specific town and have to stay there. They are not allowed to move outside 
this city.
The Berlin protestors on that place came from all across germany. So most 
of them had (illegally) left their designated
citys and their housings, to live on a central place in tents instead. And 
they demanded the full right of asylum right away. Long before each case 
was decided by a court. When most of these protestors saw that blocking the 
place did`t help
them, they left the camp. But some just moved over and occupied that old 
school building.
They kept demanding asylum to be granted to each protestor, without a 
courts decision. That was the point, when nooane could accept their demands 
and legally no politician was able to give in.
In the end, it was some kind of ransom.
They were allowed to stay in berlin, either in flats or that school, no 
matter were they originally were
coming from (designated city). So it was a win of some kind, they broke to 
law of "where they had to stay" during asylum process and were allowed to

All the rest, eg. asylum permit or not, is individually to be cleard by the

Two centuries ago it was the Belgians who colonised the Congo, first for 
its ivory, a trade which would eventually die out along with most of the
